sections.heading: A Smart pH-responsive Nano-Carrier as a Drug Delivery System: a hybrid system
sections.text:
comprised of mesoporous nanosilica MCM-41 (as a nano-container) & a pH-sensitive polymer (as smart reversible gatekeepers); preparation, characterization and in vitro
release studies of an anti-cancer drug

Abstract: A smart pH-responsive drug nano-carrier for controlled release of anti-cancer therapeutics was developed through a facile route. The nano-carrier consisted of two main parts: first, the nano-container part (that mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MCM-41) were selected for this aim); and second, pH-sensitive gatekeepers (that a pH-sensitive polymer, Poly4vinylpyridine, played this role). In the first step, MCM-41 was synthesized via template assisted sol-gel process. In the second step, polymerizable functional groups were attached onto pore entrances rather than inside walls. In the third step, polymeric gatekeepers were introduced onto pore entrances via precipitation polymerization of functionlized MCM-41 with monomers. Different methods and analysis, such as Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD), Thermo-Gravimetric Analysis (TGA), Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX), Zeta Potentials, Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS), Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) were employed to approve the successful attachment of gatekeepers. Furthermore, the release studies of methotroxate (MTX), an anti-cancer drug, were performed in different media (pH 4, 5.8 and 7.4) at 37±1 °C. The release profiles and curves show that the release rates are completely pHdependent and it proceeds with a decrease in pH. It is concluded that in the higher pH the gatekeepers are in their close state, but they switch to the open state as a consequence of repulsive forces between positively charged polymer chains appear in acidic media. The results suggest that this smart nano-carrier can be considered as an appropriate candidate to deliver therapeutics to cancerous tissues.
Keywords: Anti-cancer drugs, Drug delivery systems, MCM-41, pH-sensitive nano-carriers, Sol-gel process;

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, controlled release systems have attracted tremendous attention due to their applications in high performance drug delivery systems (DDSs). Drug delivery systems are designed to improve the therapeutic efficiency, in other words, they reduce the side effects and increase the desired effects of drugs. Researches on controlled drug delivery systems have been widely extended, not only to the typical organic, inorganic and polymeric based systems (e.g. cyclodextrins, hydrogels, micelles, microspheres, nanofibers, clays, electro-active polymers) but also to novel smart hybrid nano-materials (Abbaszad Rafi and Mahkam, 2015a; Challa et al., 2005; Chen et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2012; Dogru et al., 2015; Khimani et al., 2015; Potrč et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2005).
Contributions of nano-scale materials to both applications and fundamental researches have led to big developments in the field of disease therapy like cancer therapy. Traditional anti-cancer drugs which could not distinguish healthy and cancerous tissues, are the prevalent treatment methods primarily depend on the use of conventional cytotoxic substances thus they impart severe and serious toxicity to the normal tissues. Therefore, using methods like DDSs which improve and modify these shortcomings, seems inevitable (Peer et al., 2007). Many novel nanomaterials such as polymers and nanocomposites (Abbaszad Rafi and Mahkam, 2015b; Bazmi Zeynabad et al., 2016; Dahlman et al., 2014; Mahkam et al., 2016; Mahkam et al., 2015a; Mahkam et al., 2015b; Pathania et al., 2015), liposomes (Zhao et al., 2015), nano-fibers (Chen et al., 2015), dendrimers (Zhu et al., 2015), nano-hybrids (Michel et al., 2014), pure inorganic nanostructures have been widely used as drug carriers in drug delivery systems. Among the vast range of materials, mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) have been enormously used (Chen et al., 2012; Franklin and Guhanathan, 2014; Iwamura et al., 2005; Xu et al., 2015). Well-ordered

cylindrical-pore structure MSNs (such as SBA-15 and MCM-41) with their noticeable surface to volume ratio, uniform pore shapes, tailorable mesoporous structure, simple and cost effective synthesis, stable structures, favorable biocompatibility and also with abundant Si-OH groups that could be easily functionalized, have opened a new area for researchers in order to prepare new classes of DDSs (Abbaszad Rafi et al., 2016; Barbé et al., 2004; Vivero-Escoto et al., 2009; Xie et al., 2016; Yang et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2005). Owing to stated features, MSNs are one of the potential candidates as nano-containers for encapsulation of drugs and therapeutic agents (Scavo et al., 2015; Slowing et al., 2008). For the first time, the MCM-41-type mesoporous silica nanoparticles was reported as a DDS in 2001 (Vallet-Regi et al., 2001).
In drug delivery systems, it is highly advantageous that guest drugs are not released from drug carriers before reaching the desired tissues; however, they are mostly released in the target tissues. Additionally, the guest drugs should be released in a controlled manner. Unfortunately, in spite of all MSNs advantages, using un-modified pristine MSNs as drug carriers suffer some problems such as uncontrolled release and drug leaching. The production of stimuli-responsive “gatekeepers or capping agents” on the silica nano pores could efficiently tackle these leakage shortcomings (Giri et al., 2005; Vivero-Escoto et al., 2009). Different types of nano-particles (such as Au (Vivero-Escoto et al., 2009), ZnO (Muhammad et al., 2011), CdS (Lai et al., 2003), Fe3O4 (Slowing et al., 2008), dendrimers (Radu et al., 2004), polysaccharides and cyclodextrin (Kim et al., 2010)) have been widely used as gatekeepers or capping agent in order to block drug leakage from the mesoporous silica nanoparticles. Unfortunately, the potential uses of some of these modified mesoporous nanoparticles are still limited owing to the irreversibility of pore opening and unwanted probable cytotoxicity of the un-linked gatekeepers. To solve this problem, a combination of mesoporous silica nanoparticles with appropriate polymers as a gatekeeper

could be employed to produce a new type of reversible-switchable nano-materials that take advantages of the unique features of both mesoporous silica nanoparticles and polymers (Chang et al., 2011; Slowing et al., 2010). These polymeric gatekeepers could achieve the controlled release of loaded drugs from nanosilica channels with various kinds of external triggers (such as pH (Cui et al., 2014; Huang et al., 2015; Muhammad et al., 2011; Trendafilova et al., 2016; Xu et al., 2015), temperature (Fu et al., 2007), redox (Wang et al., 2015), light irradiation (Ferris et al., 2009) and enzyme activity (Bernardos et al., 2009)). Among these stimuli responsive nanosystems, pH-responsive systems have received specific interest, particularly for cancer therapies since it has been proved that cancerous cells have an acidic environment that is significantly lower than that of healthy cells (Yang et al., 2005). Consequently, these findings and facts have encouraged researchers to design and prepare pH-sensitive nano-materials as a drug carrier for controlled release purposes (Hu et al., 2014; Marianecci et al., 2016; Marianecci et al., 2013).
Briefly, in this work a smart stimuli responsive nano-carrier was prepared. To achieve this smart system, firstly the well-ordered cylindrical-pore structure mesoporous nanosilica (MCM-41) was selected as a drug nano-container and secondly, poly(4-vinylpyridine) (P.4-VP) employed as reversible-switchable stimuli responsive gatekeepers. The responsive polymer used in this study, poly(4-vinylpyridine), is commercially available and it has been used for the preparation of pHresponsive drug delivery systems (Liu et al., 2011; Pourjavadi et al., 2015; Sutton et al., 2007; Tian et al., 2006) owing to its pH-triggered reversible switching ability. The prepared nanocarrier was characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TGA, DLS, TEM, FE-SEM, EDX, Zeta potentials. Furthermore, the in vitro studies were performed in different pH media (7.4, 5.8 and 4) at 37±1 °C. Methotroxate (MTX), a regular drug for cancer therapy, was used as a model drug.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Cetyltrimethylammoniumbromide (CTAB), Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), Ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) and α,α’-Azobis(isobutyronitrile) (AIBN) were obtained from “Merck Co”. 4-Vinylpyridine and 3-(Trimethoxysilyl)propylmethacrylate were purchased from “SigmaAldrich Chemical Co”. All solvents were obtained from “Acros Organics” and were dried by standard methods. Methotroxate (MTX) was purchased from “United Biotech, India”. The polymerization initiator (AIBN) was purified by re-crystallization from methanol. All polymerization reactions were carried out under dry argon to exclude oxygen and moisture from the reaction systems. All other chemicals were analytical grade and used as received without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Apparatus Measurements
sections.text:
The FT-IR spectra were recorded by a Bruker Vector-22 FT-IR spectrometer. Powder samples were placed into the KBr pellet and spectra were recorded at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of the samples were recorded on a Bruker AXS model D8 Advance diffractometer using monochromatic CuKα radiation (λ=1.542 A˚), with the Bragg angle ranging from 2–70°. The amount of released drug was determined on a Philips PU 8620 UV/Vis Spectrophotometer at the λ max of the drug (around 303 nm) using a 1 cm quartz cell. Morphology and surface characteristics of the samples were studied by FE-SEM images recorded by a Scanning Electron Microscopy (TESCAN MIRA3). Thermo Gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Thermo Gravimetric Analyzer Q500 (TGA Q500). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured using a LEO TEM apparatus. sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of template containing MCM-41 (Tem/MCM-41)
sections.text: 2.40 g (6.6 mmol) of surfactant (CTAB, the sol-gel template) was dissolved in water under vigorous stirring (550 rpm, 50-60 min). Then, about 7 ml of ammonium hydroxide 25% was gradually poured and the whole mixture was stirred for an additional 15 min. Next, 10 ml (45 mmol) TEOS was added drop wise into the vigorously stirred mixture and the reaction continued for 18 h at room temperature. The mixture was centrifuged (8000 rpm for 15 min) and the white precipitate was collected and washed twice with toluene and once washed quickly with cold water-ethanol solution (5:1 v/v). The solid was dried under vacuum at 60-50 ºC overnight.

sections.heading: 2.4. Functionalization of surface and pore entrances (Methacrylate@MCM-41)
sections.text:
2.00 g of Tem/MCM-41 was heated for 8 h at 100 ºC. After cooling down to room temperature, the powder was suspended in dry toluene (10 ml) under argon atmosphere. To obtain a well dispersed suspension, the mixture was ultrasonicated at 20 kHz for 10 min, afterward 4 ml of 3- (Trimethoxysilyl) propylmethacrylate was slowly added into the magnetically stirred mixture. The reaction was continued for 72 h at 50-55 °C. After cooling down, the nano-particles were collected by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 15 min, then washed with toluene and ethanol thoroughly.
To prepare mesoporous structure (Methacrylate@MCM-41), the template that had been retained up to this step, was removed through the silica nano-pores. The template was removed by

sections.heading: 2.5. Introduce pH-responsive gates onto the pore entrances (P.4-VP@MCM-41)
sections.text: 10 ml dry toluene was poured into a pyrex tube, then 0.5 g of functionalized MCM-41 (Methacrylate@MCM-41) was added and the mixture was ultrasonicated at 20 kHz for 10 min in order to obtain a well-dispersed, bubble-free mixture. Next, 1 g (1.3 ml) of 4-VP monomer and AIBN (0.08 g) were added, then the mixture was de-gassed using Argon and sealed. The mixture was kept in oil bath with the temperature of 70-80 °C and stirred for 48 h. The solid part was separated via centrifugation (9000 rpm), then it was thoroughly washed, and soxhleted successively with toluene, THF, acidic methanol, water and acetone in order to remove residues, and finally dried under vacuum.

sections.heading: 2.6. Drug loading
sections.text:
MTX was used as a model drug to evaluate the drug loading and release behavior of the nanocarrier. In the loading procedure, nano-carrier (P.4-VP@MCM-41) was ultrasonically dispersed into an acidic buffer solution (pH 1), then drug was added to the mixture (nano-carrier to drug ratio was 7:1 w/w). The loading mixture was again ultrasonicated for 15 min and was kept under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 24 h. The loading mixture was centrifuged at 9000 rpm for 15 min to collect the MTX loaded nano-carrier. The supernatants were kept for calculating the drug loading content. sections.heading: 3.1. Preparation of smart stimuli-responsive nano-carrier
sections.text:
The schematic illustration for preparation of MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-41 are represented in scheme 1. As it can be seen, stimuli responsive nano-carrier (P.4-VP@MCM-41) consists of two main parts: the nano-container part (MCM-41) and the stimuli responsive gatekeepers (pHsensitive polymer, P.4-VP). To prepare the silica based nano-container, firstly MCM-41 type MSNs were prepared in an aqueous solution of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) in the presence of CTAB surfactant (used as a structure-directing agent) through the base catalyzed Sol–Gel process. In the next step without surfactant removing, the polymerizable groups (i.e. 3- (Trimethoxysilyl)propylmethacrylate) were mostly grafted onto MCM-41 pore entrances. During the procedure of monomer grafting, the presence of surfactant template into the MCM-41 pores are necessary for the functional group to graft and attach only to the pore entrances rather than pore inside walls (Liu et al., 2009; Wen et al., 2013). Grafting is commonly performed and proceeded by silylation of free silanol (≡Si–OH) and geminal silanol (=Si(OH)2) groups. The surfactant template can be removed via both calcination and reflux in an acidic methanol solution. Calcination at high temperatures (400 –550 °C) increases the condensation of reactive silanol groups; however, the extraction process decreases the loss of reactive silanols. In this study, to avoid decomposition of attached organic functional groups on MCM-41, the extraction process was used for template removal (Slowing et al., 2008). As a result, a well-ordered cylindrical-pore structure mesoporous silica nanoparticles with polymeirzable functional groups on its pore entrance was prepared. To attach the reversible stimuli responsive gatekeepers, the polymerizable methacrylate groups on MCM-41 co-polymerized with 4-VP via precipitation

sections.heading: 3.2. FT-IR characterization
sections.text:
The FT-IR spectra of Tem/MCM-41, pure MCM-41, Methacrylate@MCM-41, P.4-VP@MCM41 and drug loaded P.4-VP@MCM-41 are shown in Fig. 2, respectively. In the spectrum of Tem/MCM-41 (Fig. 2a), the strong bands at around 2924 cm -1 (stretching vibration of aliphatic C-H) and 1490 cm -1 (bending vibration of aliphatic C-H) come from the CTAB, which are not seen in the spectrum of pure MCM (Fig. 2b). This removal confirms that the template has been removed via washing with acidic methanol. In the spectrum of pure MCM-41 (Fig. 2b), a broad band in the region of 3424 cm -1 belongs to the symmetric stretching of the surface hydroxyl groups (Silanol, Si–OH). Bands at about 1073, 808 and 466 cm -1 are related to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of Si–O–Si. The peak in the region around 950 cm -1 is attributed to the Si–OH vibrations (Oliveira et al., 2009). The characteristic peaks of pure MCM-41 appear in all other spectra. The spectrum of Methacrylate@MCM-41 (Fig. 2c) shows not only the bands related to pure MCM-41 but also the new peaks which are related to the new attached groups (i.e. propylmethacrylate). Peaks at 1708 cm -1 and 1635 cm −1 are attributed to C=O and C=C groups, respectively. The bonds at around 2950 cm -1 is owing to stretching vibration of aliphatic C–H groups and the weak bands at 1409 cm -1 and 1455 cm -1 are related to bending vibration of aliphatic C–H groups. These new peaks prove that 3-(Trimethoxysilyl)propylmethacrylate has been successfully attached onto the nanopores entrances. The characteristic bands of P.4-VP in Fig. 2d (664, 1390 and 1670 cm -1 ) confirm successful grafting of P.4-VP onto the MCM-41 nanopore entrances. In the spectrum of drug loaded P.4-VP@MCM-41 (Fig. 2e), most of MTX bands overlap with P.4-VP@MCM-41bands; however, there are still some new bands that could

sections.heading: 3.3. XRD analysis
sections.text: The low angle range of XRD patterns for the pristine MCM-41, Methacrylate@MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-4 are depicted in Fig. 3, respectively. The X-ray diffraction of the pristine MCM-41 (Fig. 3a) shows a characteristic pattern of the mesoporous nanosilica with hexagonal symmetry. Three well resolved peaks can be seen in this pattern, the strongest one at around 2Ө=2.5 (assigned to the (100) reflection), and two weak peaks at higher angles that could be assigned to the (110) and (200) reflections (Oliveira et al., 2009). These Bragg reflections confirm the highly ordered hexagonal structure of MCM-41. In the XRD spectrum of Methacrylate@MCM-41 (Fig. 3b), the (110) and (200) reflections almost disappear, the (100) reflection loses some intensity and the position of the (100) reflection is a little shifted, suggesting that attaching the functional groups is responsible for these changes. A drastic decrease in the peak intensity is observed after polymerization of 4-VP on the surface and entrance of MCM-41 nano-channels (Fig. 3c). Interpreting that the channel entrances are mostly blocked by the outer polymeric units (Wen et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 3.4. TEM, FE-SEM, EDX and DLS analyses
sections.text:
The SEM images and EDX spectrum of pristine MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-41 are shown in figure 4. The surface of the pristine MCM-41 is smooth and the higher magnification reveals the constituent spherical nano-particles with a diameter of about 40 nm (as shown in Fig. 4a). A characteristic “sandy” morphology of P.4-VP@MCM-41 can be observed in Fig. 4b, suggesting that the polymerization has changed the morphology.

The EDX spectra of pristine MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-41can be seen in Fig. 4c and Fig. 4d, respectively. The pristine MCM-41 spectrum has the bands related to the elements that exist in the structure of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (i.e. Si, O). A moderate band related to the “C” atom can be seen in the P.4-VP@MCM-41 spectrum (Fig. 4d) that comes from polymer chains and proves that the polymer chains are attached onto MCM-41 pore entrances. In addition, the quantitative results show that “C” atom percentages (W%=19.75 and A%=19.22) which correspond to the approximate amount of polymeric parts, are in good agreement with the results obtained from TGA analysis (about W%=21.3, section 3.5).
Fig. 5 shows the Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images of pristine MCM-41 (Fig. 5a) and P.4-VP@MCM-41 (Fig. 5b1 & Fig. 5b2). The nano-size and porous structure of pristine MCM-41 are seen in the Fig. 5a. Fig. 5b1 depicts the attached polymeric layer around the nanoparticles. While polymeric segments cover and block the pore entrances, the pores of nanocarriers are detectable in the enlarged image (5b2). This reveals that the porous structure in P.4VP@MCM-41 remains almost intact.
The mean size and size distribution of nanoparticles was measured by DLS. According to DLS result (Fig. 6), the hydrodynamic diameter of P.4-VP@MCM-41 was about 300 nm. The particle size was different from that of seen in SEM or TEM images. It probably originates from this fact that the DLS measures the size of aggregated, solvated and swollen nanoparticles in solutions, while SEM or TEM could measure a sole nanoparticle in its dry and unswollen state.

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermal studies
sections.text:
Thermo-Gravimetric Analysis (TGA) was employed to estimate the modification quantity (amounts of attached groups). Fig. 7 depicts TGA thermograms of pristine MCM-41,

Methacrylate@MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-41. In the thermogram of pristine MCM-41, the weight loss (2 wt%) in the temperature ranges of 25–150 °C corresponds to the removal of physical adsorbed water. Moreover, 3 wt % loss above 150 °C comes from water removal during the condensation of adjacent silanol groups (Feng et al., 2013). In the TGA curves of Methacrylate@MCM-41 (Fig. 7b) and P.4-VP@MCM-41 (Fig. 7c), the water evaporation can be seen in the range of 25-170 °C. In the Fig. 7b, the weight loss after water evaporation can be attributed to the “Methacrylate groups” on the MCM-41. In Fig. 7c, the weight loss in the region from 280 to 560 °C is due to polymer degradation and decomposition (Sabaa, 1991). As it can be seen in Fig. 7, after heating to 800 °C, pristine MCM-41, Methacrylate@MCM-41 and P.4VP@MCM-41 shows a total weight loss of 5, 11.2, and 32.5 wt%, respectively. According to these amounts, it can be concluded that the percentage of Methacrylate groups attached to the surface and pore entrances are about 6.2 wt%. Furthermore, the amount of polymer segments is about 21.3 wt%.
3.6. Zeta potentials (ζ potentials)
Zeta potentials (ζ potentials) were employed for further verification of the attachments of P.4-VP on the MCM-41. The zeta potentials of pristine MCM-41 and P.4-VP@MCM-41 were measured at different media (pH 7.4, 5.8 and 4). As shown in Fig. 8a, pristine MCM-41 has negatively charged surfaces at the all media that is in agreement with the isoelectric point of MCM-41 (pH=3) reported elsewhere. In addition, the slight changes in zeta potentials of MCM-41 in different media can be attributed to the existence of silanol groups on MCM-41 (Yuan et al., 2011). The successful attachment of P.4-VP dramatically alters the surface property and results in an increase in positive surface charges (Pourjavadi et al., 2015). P.4-VP@MCM-41 shows positive zeta potentials in pH 5.8 and 4 (about 20 mV and 31 mV, respectively). In pH 7.4,

3.7. In vitro release studies
MTX, a classic anti-cancer drug, was utilized as a model drug to evaluate the loading and release behavior of the prepared smart nano-carrier (P.4-VP@MCM-41). The content of loaded MTX and the entrapment efficiency of the P.4-VP@MCM-41 were about 37.1% and 92.5%, respectively, which were quantitatively measured via UV/Vis spectrophotometry and calculated via Eq. (2) and Eq. (3). The in vitro drug release curves are illustrated in Fig. 9 by plotting the cumulative release of MTX from nano-carrier as a function of time at different media (pH 7.4, 5.8 and 4.0). As shown in Fig. 9, the drug release rate of P.4-VP@MCM-41 is obviously pH dependent. The amounts of released MTX from nano-carrier in pH 4 is about 93% for 3 h and reaches 100% in about 9 h, and the released amount in pH 5.8 is about 51% for 3 h and 68.5% for 12 h, respectively. In pH 7.4, the release rate and amounts are significantly decreased and it reaches about 17% after 12 h. Statistical methods based on ANOVA are the simplest approach to verify differences in release profiles. A statistically significant difference can be seen in ANOVA test (Fig. 10). Differences in release rates can be ascribed to the sensitivity of polymeric gatekeepers to pH variations. The polymer chains have pyridine heterocycle in their structures (as pendant groups) which can act as a base and attract a proton, therefore this segment and polymer chains can have two forms: protonated form and de-protonated form (Fig. 11). This polymer (P.4-VP) has a pKa of about 6 (Zaidi and Matsuura, 2009). Hence in the pH higher than pKa of P.4-VP (pH>6), the polymer chains are in their de-protonated form. In de-protonated state polymer chains become hydrophobe, therefore they do not let solution penetrate into the nano-

pores of mesoporous silica nanoparticles. In addition, in de-protonated form, the polymer chains might interact with each other via “van der waals forces” thus the chains attract each other and become contracted and assembled on the pore entrances. These cases lead to blocked pores and gates are switched to their close state, consequently release profile becomes limited and diminished in the pH 7.4 (Fig. 11). On the other hand, in acidic pH, pyridine gets a proton and then the polymer chains become protonated. In this state, the polymer chains become hydrophile thus the solution can easily penetrate into the nano-pores of mesoporous silica. Additionally, due to positive charges appeared throughout the polymer chains, electro-repulsive forces are the dominant interaction between the polymer chains. These electro-repulsive forces keep the polymer chains as far apart as possible and this lead to unblocked pore entrances. Accordingly, when the gates switch to open states, the capsulated drug molecules into the nano-pores can leach out more easily (Fig. 11).
The proportion of de-protonated pyridine molecules to protonated ones (|Py|/|PyH + |) can be assessed via “Henderson–Hasselbalch Equation” in different media (Eq. 4).
The proportion of |Py| to |PyH + | are about 10 -2 , 10 -0.2 and 10 +1.4 in pH 4, 5.8 and 7.4, respectively. The lower pH of medium, the less amount of |Py|/|PyH + | proportion (the higher content of |PyH + |) and accordingly, the more repulsive forces and the more opening in the entrance gates that all lead to fast release.
Finally, the last point is that attaching polymer chains onto the pore entrances totally reduce the release rates at all media with different pH. In the study done by Vadia et al. (Vadia and Rajput,

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A smart pH-responsive nano-carrier (P.4-VP@MCM-41) was successfully prepared using P.4VP as reversible pH-sensitive gatekeepers and MCM-41 as drug nano-container. In comparision with other similar works, in this work a facile and accurate approach has been employed in order to prepare stimuli responsive nano-carrier. To prepare the silica based nano-container, after synthesis of MSNs via surfactant assisted Sol–Gel process, without surfactant removing, the polymerizable functional groups (3-(Trimethoxysilyl)propylmethacrylate) were mostly grafted onto MCM-41 pore entrances. During monomer grafting, surfactant templates were kept into the MSN pores, so that the functional groups were grafted only onto the pore entrances rather than pore inside walls. These polymerizable functional groups were co-polymerized with 4-VP monomer via precipitation polymerization method, in order that reversible stimuli responsive gatekeepers were attached onto MCM-41 pore entrances. The nano-carrier was characterized via FT-IR, XRD, TGA, EDX, Zeta potentials, DLS, SEM, TEM and it was confirmed that polymeric gatekeepers were successfully attached on pore entrances. The polymer chains on the MCM-41 entrances could reversibly switch to open or close state triggered by pH, and therefore could regulate the release of drug from MCM-41. Results indicated that the drug release could be restrained at pH 7.4 in the blood stream; however, fast release would be realized in cancerous tissues owing to the acidic microenvironment of cancerous cells. Therefore, this nano-carrier might have a potential application in pH-sensitive delivery systems for anti-cancer drugs.
